newsitem.title: UK: Ferry jobs at risk if duty free sales go -- survey.
newsitem.headline: Ferry jobs at risk if duty free sales go -- survey.

text.p: British and Irish ferry companies could face up to 10,800 job losses in the industry if the European Commission goes ahead with plans to axe duty free sales within members states in 1999, according to a survey released on Thursday.

The survey paints a bleak picture for the industry, claiming that unless the ruling is reversed, the ferry industry will lose $5 billion in revenues a year, leading to a hike in ferry prices of 10-15 percent.
Some peripheral ferry routes could also be axed, said industry experts at a press conference earlier.

The survey was carried out by MDS-Transmodel and was commissioned by the European Travel Research Foundation. A press conference on the findings was organised by the Chamber of Shipping, the Passenger Shipping Association representing the ferry companies and the Duty Free Association.
The groups plan to use the survey as ammunition when they launch an offensive on Friday to persuade consumers and the British government to back a reversal of the EU policy.
The campaign will be launched at Heathrow airport, another duty free sales mecca, and will be followed by nationwide roadshows and the distribution of three million leaflets.
The industry hopes it can persuade the British government to raise the issue when it takes over the EU presidency next year.

"This is not a vague threat. It is something which is going to happen -- it is the law and we have to change the law." Barry Goddard, secretary general of the Duty Free Confederation, said at the press conference.
